snippet: What we wear can affect not only what people think of us, but also the way our brains work, a study involving a doctor’s coat shows.
abstract: Dr Adam D Galinsky study in The Journal of Experimental Social Cognition reports on phenomenon called enclothed recognition--the effects of clothing on cognitive processes; study found that subjects who wore a white coat that they thought belonged to a doctor exhibited sharply increased attention; study is part of a growing field called embodied cognition, which seeks to elucidate the connections between physical experiences and thought.
lead_paragraph: What we wear can affect not only what people think of us, but also the way our brains work, a study involving a doctor’s coat shows.

headline.main: Mind Games: Sometimes a White Coat Isn’t Just a White Coat
